title:
Antennas in Walls: Performance Analysis of Microstrip Patch Antennas
  Designed for Internet of Paint (IoP)
authors:
Lasantha Thakshila Wedage, Bernard Butler, Mehmet Can Vuran,
  Sasitharan Balasubramaniam and Christos Argyropoulos
abstract:
This study presents a simulated transceiver with a microstrip patch antenna
(MPA) designed to operate at 150 GHz and embedded in a dielectric paint. The
in-paint MPA (IP-MPA) is designed for the Internet of Paint (IoP) paradigm,
which envisions seamless device communication through a paint layer on walls.
Due to the paint's dielectric properties, the resonant frequency of the IP-MPA
lowers to 141.3 GHz, with lower spreading loss. The study introduces a
comprehensive channel model between transceivers in paint at arbitrary depths
as well as IP-MPA angle orientations. The best transceiver orientations are
analyzed for IoP channel performance. Our extensive evaluations shows that the
lateral waves, which propagate along the air-paint interface, have the lowest
loss, making this path the most reliable communication path between
transceivers in paint. Further, all multipaths, except the reflected paths, are
depth-independent when the received power is maximized. The findings suggest
that the proposed network of IP-MPA-enabled transceivers for IoP has the
potential to transform conventional walls into an integrated high-speed
wireless communication infrastructure.
